description: From Middle French opiner, from Latin opīnor (“to hold as an opinion”), from *opīnus (“thinking, expecting”), only in negative nec-opīnus (“not expecting”) and in-opīnus (“not expected”); akin to optō (“to choose, desire”), and to apīscor (“to obtain”); see optate and opt.

verbs.description: opine (third-person singular simple present opines, present participle opining, simple past and past participle opined)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To have or express an opinion; to state as an opinion; to suppose, consider (that).
examples: I opined that matters would soon become considerably worse.
"Your decisions," she opined, "have been unfailingly disastrous for this company."

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To give one's formal opinion (on or upon something).
examples: I had to opine on the situation because I thought a different perspective was in order.

description: From Ancient Greek ὀπός (opós, “juice of a plant”)  +‎ -ine.

entries.meaning: (biochemistry) Any of a class of organic compounds, derived from amino acids, found in some plant tumours
